
Atlas Unite  
Constitution

#### ABN: 33 987 806 924

#### 

#### 

1. **Name of the Organisation**  
   The name of the organisation shall be Atlas Unite  
2. **Purpose**  
   Support and empower volunteers to enrich the world  
3. **Vision**  
   A future where the opportunity to find purpose and joy through volunteering has been realised.  Through avenues of interest, passion, education, and community; benevolence can be a lifestyle choice  
4. **Values**  
   1. Purpose  
   2. Progress  
   3. Integrity  
   4. Ambition  
5. **Aim**  
   1. Enable collaboration as a form of aid  
   2. Allow individuals to fulfil their potential  
   3. Foster a community that promotes equality and acceptance  
   4. Promote living that’s unharmful to the planet  
6. **Objects**  
   1. Provide a diverse array of roles that address the multitude of ways individuals can contribute.  
   2. Hone systematic and technologic efficiency to maximise the quality and effectiveness of contributed time.  
   3. Publicise and promote the work of volunteers, establishing and emphasising the correlation between contribution and accomplishment.  
   4. Raise funds and receive contributions where appropriate to finance the platform and its goals  
   5. Work with other causes and charities to see projects through to fruition, and ensure all parties are operating at their greatest capacity.  
   6. Help further education towards healthier expectations and standards around individual and societal composition.  
7. **Powers**  
   1. Atlas Unite has all the powers of an organisation limited under the Corporations Act, and within the requirements of a charity with Deductible Gift Recipient (DGR) status.  
   2. Atlas Unite is its own, incorporated entity that exists separately from those who contribute.  
8. **Finance**  
   1. The income and property of the Organisation will only be applied towards the enaction and promotion of the objects of the Organisation set out in clause 6\.  
   2. All bank accounts opened for Atlas Unite shall be in the name of the organisation.  
   3. Any cheques issued by Atlas Unite shall be signed by at least two nominated signatures.  
   4. The last day of the financial year is June 30th.  
   5. None of the Organisation’s income is distributable to its members or directors, except as reasonable compensation for services rendered  
   6. The directors will oversee the formation and ongoing refinement of the Organisation’s budget and current objectives.  
   7. The Treasurer shall cause accounts to be kept of all monies received and expended by the Organisation, and the matters in which such receipt and expenditure took place.  
   8. The Organisation must also keep written records that correctly document its operations.  
   9. The Organisation must retain its records for at least 7 years.  
   10. The directors must take reasonable steps to ensure the Organisation’s records are kept safe.  
   11. Income  
       The Organisation shall assume income from:  
       1. Donations:  
          1. Made in person;  
          2. Subscription based;  
          3. Mailed cheque;  
          4. Over the phone (call/text);  
          5. Through bequest.  
       2. Products:  
          1. Percentile profits from products created;  
          2. Donated portions of proceeds from third-party products.  
       3. Access, day passes, and/or paid memberships made available to the public for the use of select:  
          1. Recreational facilities;  
          2. Creative resources;  
          3. Food and health institutions;  
          4. Work and hobby sheds;   
          5. Educational institutions; and  
          6. Any other owned facilities that could financially expedite Atlas Unite to achieve its Objects.  
       4. Events.  
       5. Sponsorship from external organisations, corporations, communities or individuals.  
          1. Independent arrangements will be agreed upon for each sponsorship, establishing:  
             1. The use of logos and cooperated branding;  
             2. Duration of the sponsorship;  
             3. Terms for the termination of sponsorship;  
             4. Resources and finances made available through arrangement;  
             5. Expectations of results produced by the arrangement.  
          2. Sponsorship does not entitle the contributor to any leverage over decisions or direction of Atlas Unite or any of its endeavours.  
          3. Sponsorship does not affirm any allegiance or dissuasion of values or objectives.  
       6. Grants from external funding and governing bodies.  
       7. Crowdfunding.  
       8. Any other means determined by the directors to further the Objects of the Organisation, limited to the  
   12. Expenditure  
       1. Subject to any restrictions imposed by the DGR status, this Constitution or any meeting, directors may approve expenditure on behalf of the Organisation.  
       2. Directors can approve the CEO or any director to expend or otherwise manage funds on behalf of the Organisation without requiring approval from the remaining directors.  
       3. Directors will act with due diligence to ensure the Organisation operates within its means to maximise the efficiency and effectiveness of any, and all, outgoings.  
       4. Funds obtained by the Organisation will be used to fulfill its purpose through the execution of projects and events, and the provision of:   
          1. Equipment;  
          2. Facilities;  
          3. Resources;  
          4. Promotions and marketing;  
          5. Provisions for Members; and  
          6. Anything that furthers the Objects of the organisation.  
       5. Expenditure considered outside of clause 8.8.4 can be raised by any Member at a General Meeting.  
       6. If it is concluded by a majority vote at a General Meeting that expenditure did not align with the Organisation’s Objects, assessment of their ongoing role must be made through a disciplinary process outlined in Process A.  
9. **Membership**  
   1. The Members of the Organisation are:  
      1. Initial members, and  
      2. Any person that applies and is approved to be a member, who accepts and abides by the values and objects of the Organisation while actively operating as a volunteer.  
   2. Every member shall carry the weight of one vote on any issue raised at a meeting.  
   3. Other than initial members, an applicant will become a member when they are entered into the register of members.  
   4. Directors shall have the power to refuse membership to an applicant, where it is considered such membership would be detrimental to the aims, values, activities, security and/or reputation of Atlas Unite.  
   5. The Register  
      1. The secretary of Atlas Unite will maintain a register of all members active within the past 7 years, containing for each member:  
         1. Name  
         2. Address  
         3. Any alternative address nominated by the member for the service of notices,  
         4. Email address,  
         5. Contact number,  
         6. Emergency contact,  
         7. Date the member was entered into the register, and  
         8. The date membership ended, if no longer active.  
      2. Active members have access to this register of members, given it is used for a cause relevant to the objectives of the Organisation.  
10. **Cessation of membership**  
    1. Any member of the association may resign their membership and any representative of a member Organisation or section may resign such position, by giving to the secretary of the association written notice to that effect two weeks in advance.  
    2. Directors may impart a warning, suspend, or cease membership of any volunteer if their conduct is determined to be;   
       1. Counterproductive to the goals and intentions of the Organisation;  
       2. Negatively impacting on the security or wellbeing of fellow volunteers;  
       3. Behaviour that conflicts with the Code of Conduct; or  
       4. Engages in conduct that could or does bring the reputation of Atlas Unite into disrepute.  
    3. The individual member or representative an organisation (as the case may be) shall have the right to be heard by the directors before the final decision is made.  There shall be a right of appeal to an independent arbitrator appointed by mutual agreement.  
    4. Cessation of membership may otherwise occur if:  
       1. Resignation is provided in writing to the secretary or appointed official  
       2. For three months, the member proves unresponsive to requests for input regarding the continuation of their membership.  
       3. The member passes away.  
       4. The Organisation enters dissolution  
    5. Those expelled from the Organisation are not allowed to return as a member unless they submit a reapplication, and it is approved by at least 66% of directors, and then 50% of members present at following General Meeting.  
    6. Forfeiture of Rights  
       A Member who or which ceases to be a Member shall forfeit all rights in and claims upon the Organisation for damages or otherwise, or claims upon its property including intellectual property rights.  
11. **Grievance Procedure**  
    The grievance procedure set out in Process B applies to disputes under this Constitution between any Member or director and:  
    1. Another Member;  
    2. A Member and the Board; or  
    3. The Organisation.  
12. **Indemnity**  
    1. Subject to the provisions of any relevant law; all members of Atlas Unite shall be indemnified by the Organisation for all acts done on its behalf, with good intent.  
    2. No volunteers shall be liable for the acts, receipts, neglects or defaults of any other member, or for any loss, damage or expense suffered by Atlas Unite, which occurs in the execution their duties, unless it arises as a result of their dishonesty, or failure to exercise due care and diligence.  
    3. The organisation will not be liable for injury or loss caused by unsafe or unsound behaviour.  
    4. In winding up the organisation, no members volunteering their time will be responsible for any debts owing.  
13. **Meetings**  
    1. Annual General Meetings  
       1. Annual General Meetings must be held once every financial year.  
       2. Even if these items are not set out in the notice of meeting, the business of an annual general meeting may include:  
          1. a review of the organisation’s activities   
          2. a review of the organisation’s finances  
          3. any auditor’s report  
          4. the election of directors, and  
          5. the appointment and payment of auditors, if any.  
       3. Before or at the annual general meeting, the directors must give information to the members on the organisation’s activities and finances during the period since the last annual general meeting.  
       4. The Chairperson of the annual general meeting must give members as a whole a reasonable opportunity at the meeting to ask questions or make comments about the management of the organisation.  
    2. General meetings  
       1. General Meetings can be held between 1 and 3 months apart, unless an absence of quorum prevents it.  
       2. Notice of a general meeting must be given to:   
          1. each member entitled to vote at the meeting   
          2. each director, and   
          3. the auditor (if any).  
       3. Notice of a general meeting must be provided in writing at least 14 days before the meeting.  
       4. Notice of a meeting cannot be provided less than 14 days before the meeting if a resolution will be moved to:   
          1. remove a director   
          2. appoint a director in order to replace a director who was removed, or  
          3. remove an auditor.  
       5. Notice of a general meeting must include:  
          1. the place, date and time for the meeting (and if the meeting is to be held in two or more places, the technology that will be used to facilitate this)  
          2. the general nature of the meeting’s business  
          3. if applicable, that a special resolution is to be proposed and the words of the proposed resolution  
          4. a statement that members have the right to appoint proxies and that, if a member appoints a proxy:  
             1. the proxy does not need to be a member of the organisation   
             2. the proxy form must be delivered to the organisation at its registered address or the address (including an electronic address) specified in the notice of the meeting, and    
             3. the proxy form must be delivered to the organisation at least 48 hours before the meeting.   
       6. If a general meeting is adjourned (put off) for one month or more, the members must be given new notice of the resumed meeting.  
       7. Quorum at general meetings   
          1. For a general meeting to be held, at least 2 non-directorial members must be present (in person, by proxy or by representative) for the whole meeting.  When determining whether a quorum is present, a person may only be counted once (even if that person is a representative or proxy of more than one member).  
          2. No business may be conducted at a General Meeting if a quorum is not present.  
          3. If there is no quorum present within 30 minutes after the starting time stated in the notice of general meeting, the general meeting is adjourned to the date, time and place that the Chairperson specifies. If the Chairperson does not specify one or more of those things, the meeting is adjourned to:  
             1. if the date is not specified – the same day in the next week  
             2. if the time is not specified – the same time, and  
             3. if the place is not specified – the same place.   
          4. If no quorum is present at the resumed meeting within 30 minutes after the starting time set for that meeting, the meeting is cancelled.  
          5. The only business that may be transacted at a postponed General Meeting is the business specified in the notice originally convening the meeting.  
    3. Directors’ Meetings  
       1. The directors may decide how often, where and when they meet.  
       2. A director may call a directors’ meeting by giving reasonable notice to all of the other directors, in writing or by any other means of communication that has previous agreed to by all of the directors.  
       3. The Elected Chairperson is entitled to chair directors’ meetings.  
       4. The directors at a directors’ meeting may choose a director to be chairperson for that meeting if the Elected Chairperson is:  
          1. Not present within 30 minutes of the starting time set for the meeting, or  
          2. Present but does not want to act as chairperson of the meeting.  
       5. Quorum at directors’ meetings  
          1. Unless the directors determine otherwise, the quorum for a directors’ meeting is more than 50% of the directors.  
          2. A quorum must be present for the whole directors’ meeting.  
       6. A directors’ resolution must be passed by a majority vote cast by the directors present and entitled to vote on the resolution.  
       7. Circular resolution of directors  
          1. The directors may pass a circular resolution without a directors’ meeting being held.  
          2. A circular resolution is passed when responses have been received from all entitled to vote, and all approve .  
          3. Each director may sign a physical or digital document, all worded the same, setting out the resolution and containing a statement that they agree to the resolution.  
          4. The Organisation may send a circular resolution by secure email to the directors and the directors may agree to the resolution by sending a reply email to that effect, containing the text of the resolution and confirmation of approval.  
          5. A circular resolution is passed when the last director signs or otherwise agrees to the resolution in the manner set out in \_\_\_Previous 2 clauses\_\_  
    4. Voting qualification  
       1. An individual’s vote of one may be deemed partial and void if there is a conflict of interests. Members must make these known before a vote on the specific topic is called.  
       2. If a member has voted on more than three subjects that are then proven to conflict with their personal interests, or are done so with intent against the values of the Organisation, they may be subject to Disciplinary Action (Process A)  
       3. Objection to voting qualification  
          1. An objection to the right of a person to attend or vote at a General Meeting (including an adjourned meeting) may only be raised at that meeting, and is referred to the Chair, whose decision is final.  
          2. An objection to right of a person to vote on a particular matter during a General Meeting can be made before the vote is called, only during that meeting.  
          3. A vote not disallowed under the objection is valid for all purposes.  
    5. Auditor's right to attend meetings  
       1. The auditor (if any) is entitled to attend any general meeting and to be heard by the members on any part of the business of the meeting that concerns the auditor in the capacity of auditor.  
       2. The organisation must give the auditor (if any) any communications relating to the general meeting that a member of the organisation is entitled to receive.    
    6. Representatives of members  
       1. An incorporated member may appoint as a representative:   
          1. one individual to represent the member at meetings and to sign circular resolutions under clause 31, and   
          2. the same individual or another individual for the purpose of being appointed or elected as a director.  
       2. The appointment of a representative by a member must:  
          1. be in writing  
          2. include the name of the representative  
          3. be signed on behalf of the member, and  
          4. be given to the organisation or, for representation at a meeting, be given to the Chairperson before the meeting starts.  
       3. A representative has all the rights of a member relevant to the purposes of the appointment as a representative.  
       4. The appointment may be standing (ongoing).  
    7. Resolutions outside General Meetings  
       1. If Members entitled to vote sign a document containing a statement that they are in favour of a resolution in terms set out in the document, to be determined in an upcoming General Meeting, those signatures will be deemed as that individual’s vote on that matter.  
       2. If 2 or more separate documents containing statements in identical terms, each of which is signed by 1 or more Members entitled to vote are deemed together to constitute one document containing the collective total of signatures.  
       3. Electronic communication purported to be signed by a Member for the purpose of this clause is deemed to be a document in writing signed by that Member.  
       4. If a Member has signed a document pertaining to a resolution that is raised in a General Meeting in which they are in attendance, they are unable to vote twice on that topic, and can not participate in the vote through show of hands.  
    8. Using technology to hold meetings  
       1. The organisation may hold meetings at two or more venues using any technology that gives the members as a whole a reasonable opportunity to participate, including to hear and be heard.    
       2. Anyone using this technology is taken to be present in person at the meeting.   
    9. Chairperson for general meetings  
       1. The elected Chairperson is entitled to Chair general meetings.  
       2. The members present and entitled to vote at a general meeting may choose a director or member to be the Chairperson for that meeting if:  
          1. there is no elected Chairperson, or   
          2. the elected Chairperson is not present within 30 minutes after the starting time set for the meeting, or  
          3. the elected Chairperson is present but says they do not wish to act as Chairperson of the meeting.   
       3. The role of the Chair includes:  
          1. Responsibility for the general conduct of the meeting and of the procedures to be adopted  
          2. Ensuring all members are permitted reasonable opportunity to make comments and ask questions (including to the auditor, if any).   
          3. Casting no vote, unless a count of other participants’ votes results in a draw, in which the Chair’s vote counts as one.  
          4. With regard to this Constitution, terminate discussion or debate on any matter whenever they consider it necessary or desirable for the proper conduct and timeliness of the meeting.  
          5. If there is a dispute about the admission or rejection of a vote, the Chair must decide it and the Chair’s decision is final.  
          6. A decision made during a meeting within the powers granted to the Chair is final.  
       4. The elected Chair may have their powers revoked for the remainder of a meeting if a movement is passed by any present Member, and garners 75% of votes.  
          1. A majority vote will be required to elect an eligible substitute Chair for the remainder of the meeting.  
    10. Adjournment of meetings  
        1. If a quorum is present, a general meeting must be adjourned if a majority of members present direct the Chairperson to adjourn it.  
14. **Members' resolutions and statements**  
    1. Members with at least 25 votes or 5% of the total votes that may be cast on a resolution(whichever is fewer) may:  
       1. give written notice to the organisation of a resolution they propose to move at a General Meeting (members’ resolution),  
       2. give a written request to the organisation that the organisation give all of its members a statement about a proposed resolution or any other matter that may properly be considered at a General Meeting(members’ statement), and/or  
       3. submit a form designated for this purpose, made available through the organisation’s online services.  
    2. A notice of a members’ resolution must set out the wording of the proposed resolution and be signed by the members proposing the resolution.  
    3. A request to distribute a members’ statement must set out the statement to be distributed and be signed by the members making the request.  
    4. Separate copies of a document setting out the notice or request may be signed by members if the wording is the same in each copy.  
    5. If the organisation has been given notice of a members' resolution under clause \_first members resolution\_, the resolution must be considered at the next General Meeting held no more than two months after the notice is given.  
    6. This clause does not limit any other right that a member has to propose a resolution at a General Meeting  
    7. The organisation must give notice of members’ proposed resolution, and provide all prevalent information, with reasonable time for it to be received by those attending the General Meeting in which the resolution will be addressed.  
       1. If it is deemed unreasonably soon for the information to be effectively dispersed to all necessary recipients, it may be moved to the following General Meeting’s agenda, but can not be further postponed.  
       2. If   
15. **Directors**  
    1. Atlas Unite shall be administered by no less than three and no more than nine directors, appointed through various means.  
       1. Elected Directors   
          Nominated and successfully elected by the Members voting at a General Meeting  
          1. No less than three and no more than seven directors are to be elected by Members.  
       2. Appointed Directors   
          The directors may itself appoint Appointed Directors, for special business acumen and/or technical skills that may be required.  
          1. Appointed Directors must still fulfill eligibility for membership of the Organisation  
          2. There can be no more than three Appointed Directors at any time  
          3. An Appointed Director appointed under this clause holds office for a period of no more than two years.  
       3. Acting Directors  
          In the case of temporary absence of no more than six months, the embarking director may nominate a person to act on their behalf.   
          1. The incoming Acting Director must be approved by a majority vote at a directors’ meeting, else they must find and appoint a Casual Director within four weeks  
       4. Casual Directors  
          Fulfilling the role to ensure meetings reach quorum, those in this role can be temporarily appointed so by a popular vote amongst the remaining directors.  
          1. This position can only be held until the following General Meeting, where a resolution for a new Elected Director must be made.  
          2. If quorum isn’t present, or a vote can’t be fulfilled, those in the role of Casual Director can resume the position only until the following General Meeting, whereupon an Elected Director must be appointed or the remaining directors must designate an Appointed Director if possible.  
          3. A Casual Director can not hold the position for more than three months in one financial year.  
    2. If there are fewer than three directors at any time, there will not be a breach of clause 14.2 if the directors has used reasonable endeavours to appoint, or have elected, additional directors who are appropriately skilled or qualified.  
    3. If there are greater than nine directors in total, or greater than seven Elected Directors, there will be no breach of clause 14.2. No director will be required to resign or be removed for the purposes of the clause. Directors must discuss in good faith whether and when any of them should resign in order to achieve the targets described in clause 14.2, without jeopardising the Organisation’s continued objects.  
    4. A person cannot hold office as director if they have been disqualified.  
       1. A Member is disqualified from becoming a director if they:  
          1. Are not older than 18 years of age.  
          2. Are not a member of Atlas Unite.  
          3. Accept a position (whether paid or unpaid) and the remaining directors believe that person’s holding of that position either gives rise to a material personal interest which cannot be reasonably managed or conflicts with any objects or values of the Organisation.  
          4. Are convicted of a criminal office that is deemed contradictory to the Organisation’s values.  
       2. A director who has been disqualified must notify the other directors of that fact immediately and is deemed to have vacated office as director.  
    5. Election and appointment of directors:  
       1. The initial directors are the people who have agreed to act as directors and who are named as proposed directors in the application for registration of the organisation.  
       2. Each of the directors must be appointed by a separate resolution, unless:  
          1. The members present have first passed a resolution that the appointments may be voted on together, and  
          2. No votes were cast against that resolution.  
       3. A person is eligible for election as director of the Organisation if they:  
          1. Are a member of the Organisation  
          2. Are nominated by two members or representatives of members entitled to vote  
          3. Has given the Organisation their signed consent to act as a director of the Organisation, and  
          4. Are not ineligible to be a director under this constitution or the ACNC Act.  
       4. Nomination for election  
          1. At least 45 days prior to the proposed date of the AGM at which a resolution or resolutions will be proposed to fill a vacancy in the position of an Elected Director, the CEO may request from Members nominations for elections to positions falling vacant, which must be received no less than 28 days prior to the AGM.  
          2. Any Member or director may nominate, in respect of each vacancy in the position of an Elected Director which is to be the subject of an election at the next AGM, one person for each position.  
          3. A nomination must:  
             1. Be in the form required by the directors;  
             2. Be approved by a director that is not the nominator; and  
             3. Be signed by the nominator, approving director and nominee.  
       5. If the number of directors is reduced to fewer than the minimum of 3, the continuing directors may act for the purpose of increasing the number of directors to 3 (or higher if required for a quorum) or calling a General Meeting, but for no other purpose.  
    6. Directors members shall convene at least twice a year.  
       1. The directors may hold their meetings by using any technology (such as video or teleconferencing) that is agreed to by all of the directors.    
       2. The directors’ agreement may be a standing (ongoing) one.    
       3. A director may only withdraw their consent within a reasonable period before the meeting.   
       4. At least three (3) directors must be present for the meeting to take place.  
       5. Voting in director meetings shall be by show of hands on a majority basis. If there is a tied vote then the Chairperson shall act as tiebreaker.  
    7. A director can resign at any time, requiring two (2) weeks notice, confirmed in writing.  
    8. A director may be required to stand down if:  
       1. They are absent from more than 3 consecutive meetings where their presence was required, without approval from 2 other directors.  
       2. Their ideals, behaviour, or attitude conflicts with the operations, values, or image of Atlas Unite.  
       3. Health or other life complications prevents them from further contributing.  
       4. Absence of active engagement and interest in fulfilling the objectives of Atlas Unite.  
       5. Become ineligible to be a director of the Organisation under the ACNC Act.  
    9. The outgoing director will be granted the opportunity to declare their cause.  
    10. The dismissal of a director is initiated at a General Meeting, and confirmed through a vote where at least  ⅔’s (66%) of the remaining directors vote for dismissal.  
    11. Directors are not financially remunerated for their services as director.  
    12. A retiring director holds office until the end of the meeting at which that director requires, but is eligible for re-election if applicable within this Constitution.  
    13. The directors must appoint a director as the Organisation’s Chairperson.  
    14. Term of office  
        1. At each Annual General Meeting:  
           1. Any director appointed by the directors to fill a casual vacancy or as an additional director must retire, and,  
           2. At least one-third of the remaining directors must retire.  
        2. The directors who must retire at each Annual General Meeting under \_\_\_\_previous clause\_\_\_ will be the directors who have been longest in office since last being elected. Where directors were elected on the same day, the director(s) to retire will be decided by vote unless they agree otherwise.  
        3. Other than Casual Directors, a director’s term of office starts at the end of the General Meeting at which they were elected, and ends with the conclusion of the General Meeting at which they retire.  
        4. Each director must retire at least once every three years.  
        5. Any retiring director may be nominated for election or re-election, subject to clause 14.17.6.  
        6. A director who has held office for a continuous period of nine years or more may only be re-appointed or re-elected by a special resolution.  
    15. Directors will not be paid fees for acting as a director, but may:  
        1. Receive payment for work they do for the Organisation, other than as a director, if the amount is no more than a reasonable fee for the work done, or  
        2. Reimburse a director for expenses properly incurred by the director in connection with the affairs of the Organisation.  
    16. Subject to the Act, where this Constitution requires that something be done by a particular time, or within a particular period, or that an event is to occur or a circumstance is to change on or by a particular date, the Board may in their discretion extend that time, period or date as it sees fit, unless specified in this constitution that approval from a General Meeting is required.  
    17. The Board may appoint any suitably qualified person to be the Organisation’s attorney, with the powers, authorities and discretions, for the period and subject to the conditions it thinks fit.  
        1. A power of attorney may contain any provisions for the protection and convenience of persons dealing with the attorney that the Board thinks fit and may also authorise the attorney to delegate (including by way of appointment of a substitute attorney) all   
    18. The Organisation may in a General Meeting by ordinary resolution remove any Director prior to the expiration of that Director’s term of office.  
        1. Unless otherwise resolved at a General Meeting, a Director removed in accordance with \_\_Parent clause\_\_ cannot be re-appointed as a Director within 3 years of their removal.  
16. **Role of Directors**  
    1. The directors are responsible for managing and directing the activities of the Organisation to achieve the objects set out in clause 6\.  
    2. The directors must comply with their duties as directors under legislation and common law:  
       1. To exercise their powers and discharge their duties within the expectations of the Organisation, with due diligence expected of anyone in such a role.  
       2. To act in good faith, furthering the progression of the Organisation towards its objects.  
       3. Not to misuse their position as director  
       4. Not to misuse the information they gain in their role as director  
       5. To disclose any perceived or actual material conflicts of interest in the manner set out in \_\_\_\_conflict of interest clause\_\_  
       6. To ensure that the financial affairs of the Organisation are managed responsibly, and  
       7. Not to allow the Organisation to operate while it is insolvent.  
    3. The directors are to manage the Organisation’s business and may exercise all of the Organisation’s powers, except those required to be exercised by the Organisation in a General Meeting under this Constitution.  
    4. The directors must decide on responsible financial management of the Organisation, including:  
       1. Exercising the Organisation’s powers to borrow or raise money, to charge any property or business or give any other security for a debt, liability or obligation of the Organisation.  
       2. How money will be managed, such as how electronic transfers, negotiable instruments or cheques must be authorised, signed, and/or otherwise approved.  
       3. Any suitable written delegations of power under clause \_\_\_\_ delegation clause\_\_\_, and  
    5. The directors cannot remove a director or auditor. Directors and auditors may only be removed by a member’s resolution at a General Meeting.  
    6. Directors may delegate any of their powers and functions to a committee, another director, an employee of the organisation (such as CEO) or any other person, as they consider appropriate.  
    7. The delegation must be recorded in the Organisation’s minute book.  
    8. The organisation may execute a document if signed by:  
       1. Two directors of the Organisation, or  
       2. A director and the Secretary.  
17. **Chief Executive Officer**  
    1. The Board must appoint a CEO  
    2. The CEO holds office on the terms and conditions (including remuneration) with the powers, duties and authorities, determined by the directors.  
    3. The exercise of those powers and authorities, and the performance of those duties, are at all times subject to the control of the directors.  
    4. The CEO’s role will be to implement the strategies, plans and policies approved by the directors and will be responsible for the management and direction of the Organisation and its finances.  
    5. Through due process, and subject to the terms and conditions of the appointment to the role, the directors may suspend or remove the powers of CEO from that office.  
    6. The CEO is entitled, subject to a determination otherwise by the Board, to attend any General Meeting, Board or Committee meeting, and may speak on any matter but does not have a vote, unless otherwise entitled to vote in their capacity as a director or Member.  
18. **Secretary**  
    1. The Organisation must have at least one secretary, who may also be a director.  
    2. A secretary must be appointed by the directors (after giving the Organisation their signed consent to act as secretary of the Organisation) and may be removed by the directors.    
    3. The directors must decide the terms and conditions under which the secretary is appointed, including any remuneration.  
    4. The role of the secretary includes:   
       1. maintaining a register of the Organisation’s members, and  
       2. maintaining the minutes and other records of General Meetings (including notices of meetings), directors’ meetings and circular resolutions.  
19. **Minutes and records**  
    1. The Organisation must, within one month, make and keep the following records:  
       1. minutes of proceedings and resolutions of General Meetings  
       2. minutes of circular resolutions of members  
       3. a copy of a notice of each General Meeting, and  
       4. a copy of a members’ statement distributed to members under clause 30\.  
    2. The Organisation must, within one month, make and keep the following records:  
       1. minutes of proceedings and resolutions of directors’ meetings (including meetings of any committees), and  
       2. minutes of circular resolutions of directors.  
    3. To allow members to inspect the Organisation’s records:   
       1. the Organisation must give a member access to the records set out in clause \_\_\_first minutes & records clause\_\_, and  
       2. the directors may authorise a member to inspect other records of the Organisation.  
20. **Conflicts of interest**  
    1. A director must disclose the nature and extent of any actual or perceived material conflict of interest in a matter that is being considered at a meeting of directors:  
       1. To the other directors, or  
       2. If all of the other directors have the same conflict of interest, to the members at the next General Meeting, or at an earlier time if reasonable to do so.  
    2. The disclosure of a conflict of interest by a director must be recorded in the minutes of the meeting.  
    3. Each director who has a material personal interest in a matter that is being considered at a meeting of directors must not, except as provided under clauses 18.4:  
       1. Be present at the meeting while the matter is being discussed, or  
       2. Vote on the matter.  
    4. A director may still be present and vote if:  
       1. Their interest arises because they are a member of the Organisation, and the other members have the same interest.  
       2. Their interest relates to an insurance contract that insures, or would insure, the director against liabilities that the director incurs as director of the Organisation.  
       3. Their interest relates to a payment by the Organisation under \_\_\_indemnity Clause\_\_\_  (indemnity), or any contract relating to indemnity that is allowed under the Corporations Act.  
       4. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) makes an order allowing the director to vote on the matter, or  
       5. The directors who do not have a material personal interest in the matter pass a resolution that:  
          1. Identifies the director, the nature and extent of the director’s interest in the matter and how it relates to the affairs of the Organisation, and  
          2. Declares that those directors are satisfied that the interest should not stop the directors from voting or being present, made known at the next General Meeting.  
21. **Notice**  
    1. Anything written to or from the Organisation under any clause in this constitution is written notice and is subject to clauses \_\_next 3 subclauses\_\_  
    2. Written notice or any communication under this constitution may be given to the organisation, the directors or the secretary by:  
       1. delivering it to the organisation’s registered office  
       2. posting it to the organisation’s registered office or to another address chosen by the organisation for notice to be provided  
       3. sending it to an email address or other electronic address declared by the organisation to the members as the organisation’s email address or other electronic address.  
    3. Written notice or any communication under this constitution may be given to a member:  
       1. in person  
       2. by posting it to, or leaving it at the address of the member in the register of members or an alternative address (if any) nominated by the member for service of notices  
       3. sending it to the email or other electronic address nominated by the member as an alternative address for service of notices (if any), or  
       4. if agreed to by the member, by notifying the member at an email or other electronic address nominated by the member, that the notice is available at a specified place or address (including an electronic address).  
    4. If the organisation does not have an address for the member, the organisation is not required to give notice.  
    5. Notice is taken to be given when:  
       1. The day it is delivered in person, or left at a the recipient’s address,  
       2. The third day after it is sent by post with the correct payment of postage costs  
       3. The business day following the day notice is sent by email, fax or other electronic method.  
22. **Security**  
    1. The organisation indemnifies each officer of the organisation out of the assets of the organisation, to the relevant extent, against all losses and liabilities (including costs, expenses and charges) incurred by that person as an officer of the organisation.   
       1. In this clause:  
          1. ‘Officer’ means a director or secretary and includes a director or secretary after they have ceased to hold that office.    
          2. ‘To the relevant extent’ means:  
             1. to the extent that the organisation is not precluded by law (including the **Corporations Act**) from doing so, and  
             2. for the amount that the officer is not otherwise entitled to be indemnified and is not actually indemnified by another person (including an insurer under an insurance policy).  
    2. The indemnity is a continuing obligation and is enforceable even when that person is no longer an officer of the organisation.   
    3. A director has a right of access to the financial records of the organisation at all reasonable times.  
    4. If the directors agree, the organisation must give a director or former director access to:   
       1. certain documents, including documents provided for or available to the directors, and  
       2. any other documents referred to in those documents.   
23. **Alteration to the Constitution**  
    1. Proposals for amendments to this constitution, or dissolution must be delivered to the secretary in writing.  The secretary, in conjunction with all other officers, shall then decide on the date of a forum meeting to discuss such proposals, giving at least a fortnight (14 days) clear notice.  
    2. Any changes to this constitution must be agreed by at least two thirds of those members present and voting at any general meeting.  
24. **Dissolution**  
    1. In the event of the Organisation being dissolved, the amount that remains after such dissolution and the satisfaction of all debts and liabilities shall be transferred to another Organisation(s) with similar purpose(s) which is not carried on for the profit or gain of its individual members.  
    2. The decision as to the charity or charities to be given surplus assets must be made by a special resolution of members at or before the time of dissolution.  
       1. Surplus assets must not be distributed to an individual member or former member of the organisation.  
       2. If the members aren’t able to decide on any external charitable purpose(s), the organisation may apply to the Supreme Court to make this decision.

Process A

Disciplinary Action

1. The dispute resolution procedure in this clause applies to disputes (disagreements) under this constitution between a member or director and:  
   1. one or more members  
   2. one or more directors, or  
   3. the organisation.  
2. A member must not start a dispute resolution procedure in relation to a matter which is the subject of a disciplinary procedure under clause 17 until the disciplinary procedure is completed.  
3. Those involved in the dispute must try to resolve it between themselves within 14 days of knowing about it.  
4. If those involved in the dispute do not resolve it under clause 16.3, they must within 10 days:  
   1. tell the directors about the dispute in writing  
   2. agree or request that a mediator be appointed, and  
   3. attempt in good faith to settle the dispute by mediation.  
5. The mediator must:  
   1. be chosen by agreement of those involved, or  
   2. where those involved do not agree:  
1. for disputes between members, a person chosen by the directors, or  
2. for other disputes, a person chosen by either the Commissioner of the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission or the president of the law institute or society in the state or territory in which the organisation has its registered office.  
   1. A mediator chosen by the directors under clause 16.5(b)(i):   
      1. may be a member or former member of the organisation  
      2. must not have a personal interest in the dispute, and  
      3. must not be biased towards or against anyone involved in the dispute.  
   2. When conducting the mediation, the mediator must:  
      1. allow those involved a reasonable chance to be heard  
      2. allow those involved a reasonable chance to review any written statements  
      3. ensure that those involved are given natural justice, and  
      4. not make a decision on the dispute.   
2. **Disciplining members**  
   1. In accordance with this clause, the directors may resolve to warn, suspend or expel a member from the organisation if the directors consider that:  
      1. the member has breached this constitution, or   
      2. the member’s behaviour is causing, has caused, or is likely to cause harm to the organisation.   
   2. At least 14 days before the directors’ meeting at which a resolution under clause 17.1 will be considered, the secretary must notify the member in writing:  
      1. that the directors are considering a resolution to warn, suspend or expel the member  
      2. that this resolution will be considered at a directors’ meeting and the date of that meeting  
      3. what the member is said to have done or not done   
      4. the nature of the resolution that has been proposed, and  
      5. that the member may provide an explanation to the directors, and details of how to do so.  
   3. Before the directors pass any resolution under clause 17.1, the member must be given a chance to explain or defend themselves by:  
      1. sending the directors a written explanation before that directors’ meeting, and/or  
      2. speaking at the meeting.  
   4. After considering any explanation under clause 17.3, the directors may:  
      1. take no further action  
      2. warn the member  
      3. suspend the member’s rights as a member for a period of no more than 12 months  
      4. expel the member   
      5. refer the decision to an unbiased, independent person on conditions that the directors consider appropriate (however, the person can only make a decision that the directors could have made under this clause), or  
      6. require the matter to be determined at a General Meeting.  
   5. The directors cannot fine a member.  
   6. The secretary must give written notice to the member of the decision under clause 17.4 as soon as possible.  
   7. Disciplinary procedures must be completed as soon as reasonably practical.  
   8. There will be no liability for any loss or injury suffered by the member as a result of any decision made in good faith under this clause.

Process B

Grievance Procedure

CEO

Directors

Organisation
